title: Wisdom in Worship and Wealth
shortSummary: Ecclesiastes 5 offers practical wisdom on approaching God with reverence, the seriousness of vows, and the vanity of wealth without contentment. It contrasts the folly of rash speech and unfulfilled promises with the blessing of enjoying God's gifts with a grateful heart.
timeline: c. 10th century BC - Solomon's reign and wisdom literature period

keyCharacters.name: The Preacher (Qoheleth)
keyCharacters.description: The author and speaker who imparts wisdom on fearing God, the proper attitude in worship, and the fleeting nature of riches.

definitions.definition: A solemn promise made to God, which must be fulfilled to avoid sin and dishonor.
Offerings made without proper reverence or understanding, reflecting foolishness rather than true worship.
Empty or meaningless pursuits that ultimately bring no lasting value or satisfaction.
A reverent awe and respect for God's holiness and authority, leading to obedience and worship.

outline.heading: Approach God with Reverence and Restraint
outline.description: The Preacher warns against careless speech and foolish sacrifices in God's presence, emphasizing the importance of listening more than speaking and the need for humility before God.

outline.heading: The Seriousness of Vows
outline.description: A solemn admonition to fulfill vows made to God promptly, highlighting that God takes vows seriously and is displeased with those who make promises they do not keep.

outline.heading: Observation on Injustice and Authority
outline.description: The Preacher notes the reality of oppression and corruption but reminds that God is sovereign over all earthly powers, including kings and rulers.

outline.heading: The Vanity of Loving Wealth
outline.description: A reflection on the insatiable desire for riches and abundance, showing that such love leads to dissatisfaction and unrest rather than true contentment.

outline.heading: The Futility of Hoarded Riches and the Blessing of Enjoyment
outline.description: The Preacher observes the evil of wealth hoarded to one's harm and the inevitability of death without possessions, contrasting this with the good and comely gift of enjoying one’s labor and God’s blessings.

application: Approach God with humility and listen more than you speak in worship and prayer to honor His holiness.
Be faithful and prompt in fulfilling any vows or commitments made to God, recognizing their spiritual weight.
Guard against the love of money and material abundance as they can never satisfy the soul.
Find joy and contentment in the daily blessings God provides, trusting Him as the sovereign giver of all good things.

keyVerses.text: Keep thy foot when thou goest to the house of God, and be more ready to hear, than to give the sacrifice of fools: for they consider not that they do evil.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the importance of reverence and listening in worship, warning against foolish offerings.

keyVerses.text: When thou vowest a vow unto God, defer not to pay it; for he hath no pleasure in fools: pay that which thou hast vowed.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights the seriousness of vows and the necessity of fulfilling promises made to God.

keyVerses.text: He that loveth silver shall not be satisfied with silver; nor he that loveth abundance with increase: this is also vanity.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals the emptiness of greed and the futility of seeking satisfaction in wealth alone.

keyVerses.text: Behold that which I have seen: it is good and comely for one to eat and to drink, and to enjoy the good of all his labour that he taketh under the sun all the days of his life, which God giveth him: for it is his portion.
keyVerses.significance: It affirms the biblical principle of enjoying God’s provision as a gift and portion in life.
